awd_titl_txt: CIF:Small:GOALI:Signal Processing and Coding for Two-Dimensional Magnetic Recording Channels
awd_abstract_narration:
Industry is approaching the limit of the data storage density possible on magnetic disks with the traditional approach of reading and writing data on a single-track. This research considers an alternate approach called two dimensional magnetic recording (TDMR), wherein bits are read and written in two dimensions on conventional magnetic disks. A key problem in TDMR is that a given magnetic grain on the disk retains the polarization of the last bit written on it; hence, if a grain is large enough to contain two bit centers, the oldest bit will be overwritten by the newer one if they have different polarities. Bits are read from the disk by a 2D read head. Because bits are stored at high density, the signal read from a given bit suffers 2D intersymbol interference (2D ISI) from bits in both down and cross track directions. This research allows industry to continue to refine conventional magnetic recording technology, without radical redesign of the recording medium.

The investigators study 2D signal processing and coding techniques to combat grain overwriting and 2D ISI in TDMR, with the goal of approaching the recently estimated channel capacity of 0.5 bit/grain. Specific objectives include:
1) Investigate detectors for the TDMR magnetic grain channel based on three channel models: rectangular-grain model, discrete-grain Voronoi model, and Voronoi model. 
2) Integrate grain channel detection with 2D ISI detection and with channel decoding. 
3) Develop capacity bounds for the TDMR/ISI channel models.
4) Evaluate the developed algorithms against the capacity bounds and against experimental data from the project s industrial partner Hitachi Global Storage Technologies, a Western Digital company.

por.por_cntn:
Industry is approaching the limit of the data storage density possible on conventional magnetic disks, which write and read data bits on single one-dimensional (1D) tracks. This project considers an alternate approach originally proposed by co-PI Wood called two dimensional magnetic recording (TDMR), wherein bits are read and written in 2D on conventional magnetic disks. These disks have magnetic grains of different sizes packed randomly onto the disk surface. In high-density TDMR with 1 to 3 magnetic grains per coded bit, the number of channel bits may be larger than the number of media grains to support them in a given local area. Thus, occasionally a bit will not be written on any grain, and will be “overwritten” by bits on surrounding grains. Detection of overwritten bits is an important goal in TDMR detector design. Because bits are stored at high densities, the signal read from a given bit will suffer 2D intersymbol interference (2D ISI) from adjacent bits in both down and cross track directions. This project investigates advanced 2D signal processing and coding techniques for TDMR channels that can approach the recently estimated channel capacity of about 0.5 information bit/grain. By contrast, current generation hard disk drives achieve about 0.1 bit/grain.

Most of the project's publications considered magnetic grain models where grains are constructed as the nearest neighbor (Voronoi) regions of randomly distributed points (grain nuclei) in 2D space; this is a fairly accurate model of actual magnetic grains. Various simplified write and read models are employed to simulate writing and reading data onto/from the media models. Six publications consider TDMR systems with grain-state and/or 2D-ISI detectors based on the Bahl-Cocke-Jelinik-Raviv (BCJR) trellis algorithm; these detectors exchange probabilistic estimates of the information bits with irregular repeat accumulate (IRA) error correction codes, to form an iterative "turbo-equalization" system that can detect and correct bit errors due to overwrites and/or 2D ISI. These publications have demonstrated that user information densities of  9 Terabits/in2 can be achieved on magnetic disks with (future envisioned) grain densities of 20 Teragrains/in2, under the simplified read/write and media model assumptions; this is nearly an order of magnitude increase over current generation hard disk information densities of about 1Tb/in2.

Three publications consider a more computationally intensive method that uses 2D generalized belief propagation (GBP) to estimate the grain states (grain nuclei locations) over a local area in order to detect overwritten bits; the GBP-based systems have demonstrated density gains of about 2% compared to the BCJR-based 2D-ISI equalizers.  Two publications developed a local area influence probability (LAIP)-based Y-effect detector which was 10000 times faster than the GBP-based detector, and demonstrated density gains of about 23% compared to the GBP-based equalizers. The LAIP-based detector can also be easily modified for other (more accurate) magnetic media models.

Two publications developed a TDMR turbo equalization system employing a random Voronoi magnetic grain model. The system introduces a non-linear mapping function to transfer soft information to the IRA decoder and a special overwrite estimator that enables turbo-iterations between equalizer and channel decoder. These enhancements gave user bit density gains as well as signal-to-noise-ratio gains. Two additional related publications present a signal processing and coding system for processing TDMR data generated by a grain flipping probability (GFP) model, which is based on highly realistic micromagnetic recording simulations. This system achieves up to 1.7 Tb/in2 user bit density at 18 nm spacing between track centers; this is among the highest achieved densities for micromagnetic recording simulations. In two recent publications, we present an extrinsic information transfer (EXIT) chart based design technique for IRA error correction codes used in TDMR turbo-equalization systems; the improved IRA code designs achieve 6% higher user densities than "generic" IRA codes designed for standard additive white Gaussian noise channels. 

Regarding broader impacts, our collaboration with industry partner HGST in this project helped us become a member of the advanced storage technology consortium (ASTC). ASTC is a forum for collaborative joint R&D efforts among storage industry participants, customers, suppliers, universities and laboratories with a goal to shorten the time from invention to product. We have gained valuable insight into the problems of importance to the magnetic disk drive industry, and we have communicated our research results at bi-annual ASTC research meetings. Our research has influenced ASTC's approach to TDMR; some of our turbo-equalization techniques have the potential to be included in future hard disk drives that employ TDMR.

Three project students graduated with the MS degree. One student graduated with a PhD degree. Two other students are currently pursuing their PhD degrees. Three undergraduate research students were supported by the project; two subsequently decided to pursue graduate study. The project promoted development of engineering research skills among traditionally underrepresented groups, as one of the undergraduate students was Hispanic-American, and one of the graduate students was from Latin America.
